title: Two temple guardians
description: Beeld van een tempelwachter: Naraen kongo (Ungyo), hout met resten van polychromie.
plaqueDescriptionEnglish: These guards stand at the entrance to a temple to ward off evil. They are holding a vajra, with which to crush ignorance. Their open and shut mouths represent the first and last letters of the Japanese script: A and N: this symbolises the totality of sounds and letters, of knowledge. Worshippers who enter the temple through the gate symbolically receive that knowledge.

acquisition.creditLine: Purchased with the support of the BankGiro Lottery, the M.J. Drabbe-fonds/Rijksmuseum Fonds, made available by ABN-AMRO, the Mondriaan Stichting and the Vereniging Rembrandt, with additional funding from the Prins Bernhard Cultuurfonds

documentation: Annette Löseke en Anna Grasskamp, 'Framing 'Asia' : results from a visitor study at the Rijksmuseum's Asian Pavilion', Aziatische Kunst 44 (2014) nr. 2, p. 50, fig. 1.
Renée Steenbergen, 'Chronology', Aziatische Kunst 40 (2010) nr. 2, p. 25-34, afb. 19.
E. van Dalen, 'De aanwinst : 14de-eeuwse tempelwachters', Oog 2 (2008) 3, p. 98, 99.
'Japanse tempelwachters en 18de-eeuwse loden beelden', in: Rijksmuseum Amsterdam Jaarverslag 2007, Amsterdam 2008, p. 71 [uitklapblad].
Peter Hecht, '125 jaar en een agenda die nog altijd actueel is', Bulletin van de Vereniging Rembrandt 18 (2008), nr. 2, p. 8-9.
H. Washizuka et al., Enlightenment Embodied : The Art of the Japanese Buddhist Sculptor (7th-14th Centuries), New York (Japan Society) 1997.
V. Harris en K. Matsushima, Kamakura : The Renaissance of Japanese Sculpture 1185-1333, London (The British Museum) 1991, p. 28-40, nr. 1.
longTitle: Two temple guardians, anonymous, c. 1300 - c. 1400
subTitle: h c.237cm × w 146cm × d 62.5cm
scLabelLine: Japan, 14th century, wood with traces of painting

label.title: Two temple guardians
label.makerLine: Japan, 14th century, wood with traces of painting
label.description: Temple guardians are placed at the entrance to a temple to ward off evil. Each of these figures holds a vajra for crushing ignorance. Their open and closed mouths represent a and un, the first and final syllables of Siddham (a script used to write Sanskrit): these syllables symbolize all spoken sounds and scripts, thus all knowledge. Worshippers who enter the temple precinct through the guardians’ gate symbolically acquire this knowledge.
